messages.content:
Thanks for this update <@582311094438199328> and the walk through.

You should indeed not have to do `InfraInterfaceL2L3 ->  InfraIPAddress` and `InfraIPAddress -> InfraInterfaceL2L3 `  if the relationship is bi-directionnal.

So if in your case `IPAddress` is before `InfraInterfaceL2L3`, you should have it only in `InfraInterfaceL2L3`, if the relationships is not properly set in the UI on `InfraIPAddress` afterwards, it must be an issue with the identifier.

Oh right, and I had to add `status` to the nautobot v2 schema for IPAddress, right above line 584:

```yaml
      - name: status
        peer: StatusGeneric
        optional: true
        cardinality: one
        kind: Attribute
```

Update for posterity:

Using the official infrahub guide for [Creating a new sync instance](https://docs.infrahub.app/sync/guides/creation), I had to make the following edits for Nautobot v2. 

Regarding the synchronization order in Step 2:

 - Uncomment `InfraDevice`, `InfraInterfaceL2L3`, and `InfraIPAddress` lines.
 - Move `InfraIPAddress` line before `InfraInterfaceL2L3`.

And, in Step 3, I uncommented the following sets of lines for the schema mapping.

379-381:
```
       # - name: location
       #   mapping: location
       #   reference: LocationGeneric
```
and 473-475:
```
       # - name: ip_addresses
       #   mapping: ip_addresses
       #   reference: InfraIPAddress
```

The above then shows an error in the initial loading step for IPAddress as it cannot find the L2L3 interfaces, but then it's fine after sycning.  When I didn't have them in this order, IP addresses were not associated with the interfaces.  Chicken or the egg situation, I guess.

Otherwise, my issues from a couple of weeks ago stemmed from initially not regenerating the models and adapter code after changes to config.yml.

Hi <@1133022375051542558> I have an update--I was able to get a hold of a slightly newer lab nautobot instance (2.3.6) and it went much better (VLANs and Prefixes loaded), but still stalled out with all comments removed:
```
Nautobot: Loading 1/1 vlans
Loading InfraVRF
Nautobot: Loading 0/0 vrfs
Loading InfraDevice
Nautobot: Loading 6/6 devices
Loading InfraPrefix
Nautobot: Loading 17/17 prefixes
Loading InfraInterfaceL2L3
Nautobot: Loading 28/28 interfaces
Error: An error occurred while loading Nautobot: Unable to find the field 
ip_addresses under <class 'nautobot.sync_models.InfraInterfaceL2L3'>
Aborted.
```
If I switched the order of IP Addresses and L2L3 interfaces, it then complained of not being able to find the field `status`, so I poked around in the `sync_models.py` code that was generated before.  I noticed that these classes were missing these fields, so I added them, and it worked. üôÇ

sure, here you go:
```
infrahub-sdk==1.12.1
infrahub-sync==1.2.0
```
The main reasons for the comment was time used during tests üòÖ, nothing regarding breaking changes
Could you confirm the infrahub sdk and infrahub sync version you are using ?

I used the example schema and sync configuration given in the [docs for the Nautobot adapter](https://docs.infrahub.app/sync/adapters/nautobot), and that config.yml already had 3 of the above models commented out from the "order" list: Prefix, InterfaceL2L3 and IPAddress.  Could there be a breaking change between v2.1.4 and v2.4.8, or was there some other reason those were already commented out?  I started by commenting out everything from InfraVLAN on down, then uncommented them one by one until I had a list that worked.  Here are the rest of the `-diff` errors (beyond the VLAN one I pasted above) that I got during this process that led me to recomment the models in question:
```
Loading InfraDevice
Nautobot: Loading 6/6 devices
Loading InfraPrefix
Nautobot: Loading 17/17 prefixes
Error: An error occurred while loading Nautobot: 'NoneType' object is not iterable
Aborted.
```
and
```
Loading InfraDevice
Nautobot: Loading 6/6 devices
Loading InfraInterfaceL2L3
Nautobot: Loading 28/28 interfaces
Error: An error occurred while loading Nautobot: Unable to find the field 
ip_addresses under <class 'nautobot.sync_models.InfraInterfaceL2L3'>
Aborted.
```
and finally:
```
Loading InfraFrontPort
Nautobot: Loading 0/0 front-ports
Loading InfraIPAddress
Nautobot: Loading 31/31 ip-addresses
Unable to locate the node ip_prefix ad646c55-cd6b-42bb-b991-f84006a97d09
Unable to locate the node interfaces 495a7a0b-99ac-4bab-b62c-0f6bc56c9570
Error: An error occurred while loading Nautobot: Unable to find the field status under <class 'nautobot.sync_models.InfraIPAddress'>
Aborted.
```

Hello <@582311094438199328> ,

This issue was not known, could you confirm the schema you use on infrahub with the example configuration for the sync ?

I do not reproduce the issue with the demo.nautobot.com (in 2.4.8) , the example config and the example schema for nautobot v2

To follow up, I successfully got infrahub-sync to complete with the Nautobot adapter (for v2+) on my tiny containerlab network instance (nautobot v2.1.4) -- woo hoo!  It errored on VLAN:
```
Loading InfraRouteTarget
Nautobot: Loading 0/0 route-targets
Loading InfraVLAN
Nautobot: Loading 1/1 vlans
Error: An error occurred while loading Nautobot: 'NoneType' object is not iterable
Aborted.
```
So I commented that out from the sync order section, and I reinstated some that were commented in the sample config.yml, but ultimately had to go back and recomment most of them out because they also caused errors.  For this missing data I am probably going to look at the CSV import method you mentioned.  

Regarding infrahub-sync, are these known issues with the adapter then, and TBD in terms of a fix?  Nothing in the github issues looks relevant to me.  Ones I had to comment out:
```
  #"InfraVLAN",
  #"InfraPrefix",
  #"InfraInterfaceL2L3",
  #"InfraIPAddress",
```
Thanks!

referenced_message.content: For data sync, you can DIY, or you can use Infrahub Sync. That's it's purpose in life. You'd need a create a sync adapter to map your other data source (a DB, a JSON file, ServiceNow, some DDI solution, whatever) if it's not one we've got an example already: IP Fabric, LibreNMS, Nautobot, Netbox, Observium, Peering Manager, Slurp'it

messages.content: oh cool, yes that is very helpful. I think I did run across that but didn't click since I was focusing on getting data into infrahub

And not part of the original question, but somewhat related: once you've got the data in Infrahub, if you want to render configs for Arista from that data, and even generate a containerlab config file, then push the configs to containerlab, here's a working example: https://docs.infrahub.app/demo/demo-dc-fabric

embeds.title: Demo-dc-fabric | Infrahub Documentation
embeds.description: This repository demos key Infrahub features using an example data center running VxLAN / EVPN and firewalls. It demonstrates the capabilities to use Infrahub with Arista AVD and Containerlab. Infrahub generates configurations that AVD deploys to a Containerlab topology.

messages.content: oh ok, I may do that sometime! thanks!
Arista and Juniper already output json natively so I think I'm going to see if I can get somewhere with that .
Finally, if you want to brainstorm anything specific, ping me and we can get one of the automation experts around here to jump on a call and give you suggestions or strategies we've seen elsewhere!
thank you! really appreciate it
ah ok, interesting.

<@695690467056025690> wrote the underlying open source library (diffsync) for Nautobot ssot when he was working there. And Infrahub Sync uses the same library, but has other parts around to handle schema mapping, large scale data sync and other items.

And finally data reconciliation would be using something like Slurp'it, SuzieQ, IP Fabric, Forward Networks or some other open source or commercial tool that gathers state in a structured way, and using Infrahub Sync to continuously do this.
OK that makes sense, it's kind of like ssot integration in nautobot

For data sync, you can DIY, or you can use Infrahub Sync. That's it's purpose in life. You'd need a create a sync adapter to map your other data source (a DB, a JSON file, ServiceNow, some DDI solution, whatever) if it's not one we've got an example already: IP Fabric, LibreNMS, Nautobot, Netbox, Observium, Peering Manager, Slurp'it
ok, thank you! Lots to digest here.

For one-time import, there's many options:
- Write your own script, use Infrahub python SDK to make it easy to push data to Infrahub
- CSV import. See Emma: https://docs.infrahub.app/emma
- `infrahubctl object load` to pull in data from properly structured YAML files: https://docs.infrahub.app/infrahubctl/infrahubctl-object
- Infrahub sync: https://docs.infrahub.app/sync (Netbox, Nautobot and a number of other sync adapters already published)

embeds.title: Emma | Infrahub Documentation
embeds.description: Emma is the experimental little sister of Otto, and she is to help you interact with Infrahub.

embeds.title: infrahubctl object | Infrahub Documentation
embeds.description: Manage objects in a remote Infrahub instance.

embeds.title: Infrahub Sync | Infrahub Documentation
embeds.description: Infrahub Sync is a versatile Python package that synchronizes data between a source and a destination system. It builds on the robust capabilities of diffsync to offer flexible and efficient data synchronization across different platforms, including Netbox, Nautobot, and Infrahub. This package features a Typer-based CLI for ease of use, supporti...

messages.content:
So I'll start off brief with various paths here, but as you said no two infrastructures/networks are the same, and schemas can all be different. I'm sure the team will also chime in here. First, there's a few paths:
- One-time import
- Data sync (unidirectional or bidirectional)
- Data reconciliation (some other tool gets live device state, and you want to compare/reconcile with intended state in Infrahub)

I have googled a bunch but can't find this exactly, and that probably makes sense because no two implementations are likely to use the same schema, but is there a config importer library or something like that?  Say I have an existing Arista eos (or ceos in containerlab, that already has a config). I want to create a schema with all the relevant stuff I want to model, and then import several switches at once.  I saw reference to transforms but haven't found a good example so far, but may not be looking in the right place.
